Sometimes, ginseng makes armies.

Introduction

Something I think is all too often forgotten is that Nagasaki wasn’t just where the rest of the world had its one carefully controlled way in to Japan. It was also where Japan reached out to the rest of the world. This was especially the case when it came to Qing dynasty China. Merchants based in Nagasaki handled exports on behalf of domains that had things to send out to the wider world. There may have been only one Dutch ship a year allowed, but many more Chinese ships were allowed. It was a very lucrative trade.

Which brings us to Aizu domain and ginseng. Ginseng is a root vegetable common in East Asian cuisine as well as an important ingredient in traditional Chinese medicine. Aizu domain, a mountainous, landlocked domain in the Tohoku region, was a ginseng growing region in the Edo period. Even today, the Aizu district remains one of very few ginseng growing regions in Japan.

Handling ginseng exports to Qing dynasty China was Nagasaki merchant Adachi Jinjūrō. Originally from Tajima Province, he moved to Nagasaki and went into the ginseng export business. And it was there that he became the official ginseng exporter for Aizu domain from 1830 to 1866.

Ginseng was a cash crop. Taxes got mostly paid in rice, but of course, you can’t live on rice alone, and aside from the other staples, there were cash crops that varied from domain to domain and region to region. In Aizu, the cultivation of ginseng would prove to be a lifesaver.

Saving Strained Finances

Aizu domain had always been in a position of high honor in the Shogunal administration, but also great material demand. The Shogunate placed Aizu domain where it did, under a daimyo who was the Shogun’s relative, in order to keep an eye on potentially hostile rivals, most notably house Date of Sendai. In the 19th century the Shogunate routinely called on Aizu to join coast defense missions in the face of increasing foreign incurions off Japanese waters. We’ve covered a bunch of these incidents on the podcast before, but to sum up, the growth of the Pacific whaling trade,

and the expansion of steam power, along with the eastward expansion of the Russian empire, meant that a whole lot of foreign vessels were straying into Japanese waters and an increasing number of shipwrecked sailors actually coming ashore. The Shogunate assigned Aizu domain, Sendai domain, and other major Tohoku domains to coast defense duty in response. But the thing about these missions is that they were expensive, as such missions are even today. The Shogunate made it a matter of standing policy to drain domains’ finances via the alternate attendance system to forestall revolt, so this was expense on top of expense. Consider also that this was squarely in the era when the Tenmei and Tenpo Famines were badly impacting domains’ incomes, especially in the Tohoku region.

When the Shogunate issued an order it was very hard to get out of obeying it no matter what the financial burden, and for the Matsudaira family of Aizu domain, even moreso. The legal code that was the basis for its entire ethos obliged it. So the domain went, to Hokkaido and to the Boso Peninsula, and nearly bankrupted itself in the process.

Ginseng saved it, but the ginseng itself goes back further than this. It was third generation Aizu lord Matsudaira Masakata who first petitioned the Shogunate for a grant of ginseng seeds, which he had planted in the Oyakuen, an herb garden in Aizu that still exists today. But it wasn’t until 1803 and the tenure of reformist Aizu domain elder Tanaka Harunaka (1747-1808) that the ginseng cultivation was seriously expanded and turned into an industry. It was one of a package of measures Tanaka promoted to turn the domain’s finances around, along with cotton, safflower, and increases in sericulture and sake production. Tanaka died in 1808, but the industries he set up would sustain the domain through the hard times of the Tenpo famine and the ensuing Bakumatsu period.

Enter Adachi Jinjūrō, circa 1830. The domain contracted him to handle ginseng exports to China, in the interest of improving the domain’s finances. There followed 36 years of record profits for both Adachi and Aizu domain, and the introduction to Aizu of other things from Nagasaki. Once every two years, Adachi would trek out to Aizu to meet with domain officials. This is also when Adachi brought goods from Nagasaki that would have been of interest to Aizu men as novelties or curiosities. One rather notable one whose current ubiquity we may take for granted was kasutera cake. Another was a kind of Nagasaki kite called a Tōjindako– a Chinese kite.

But this isn’t all that Adachi’s management of the Aizu ginseng trade made possible.

Ginseng to guns

For his service to the domain, Adachi was given bushi status, the position of junior councilor (wakadoshiyori) in the administration, and a stipend of 500 koku. As a now senior Aizu retainer, he was called Adachi Kenmotsu.

And the lucrative ginseng trade didn’t just save the domain’s finances and personally enrich and elevate Adachi. It also made its breakneck military modernization possible. Aizu’s 1868 arms dealers the Schnell brothers are famous, but these earlier Prussians, Carl Lehmann and Oskar Hartmann, were first. Aizu retainers Yamamoto Kakuma and Nakazawa Tatewaki contracted with them to import guns. It was Adachi Jinjūrō that connected Yamamoto and Nakazawa with Lehmann and company, through whom Aizu domain ordered 4300 breech-loading Snider-Enfield rifles, of which Aizu was to acquire 1300 and Kii domain, a major domain in central Japan that was nominally allied with Aizu, received 3000. This was a significant investment made at a time when domains across Japan were rapidly modernizing their fighting forces in whole or in part. Aizu, as with the rest of the northern domains, was far from Nagasaki and the usual port of entry for imports like guns, but having that Nagasaki based official made the process more convenient for the domain. It was also necessary because Aizu was actively engaged in the urban warfare that characterized life in and around Kyoto in the 1860s.

However, the coming of the Boshin War meant that the new Satsuma-Chōshū led imperial government confiscated that year’s ginseng export. While the Sniders indeed arrived, Saga domain intercepted them, and they never reached the hands of the Aizu troops who needed them the most. The bill went unpaid by Aizu domain, understandably, and some years later the Lehmann-Hartmann Company sued the now defunct Aizu domain for unpaid bills, and the records are now digitized and in the JACAR (Japan Center for Asian Historial Records) operated by the National Diet Library, where you can read them today.

But that wasn’t the end of Aizu or Adachi Jinjūrō.

The Bloodsucking Carpet

Adachi Jinjūrō performed one last act of service to Aizu domain before its end. When Aizu-Wakamatsu Castle fell, retired daimyo Matsudaira Katamori came out of the castle to surrender to the imperial forces in a short ceremony outside the castle gate.

Akizuki Teijirō, an Aizu domain liaison officer later known for having worked alongside Lafcadio Hearn, who called him a man who was like a god, penned a poem that I think sums up that day well.

The way of loyalty and filial piety is on the wane

What have I done for these forty-odd years?

Alone I lament, and having had no chance to test this precious sword

I plant the flag of surrender outside Wakamatsu Castle’s gate.

至 今 忠 孝 道 方 虧

四 十 余 年 何 所 為

独 恨 宝 刀 未 全 試

松 城 門 外 植 降 旗

The surrender ceremony, happening as it was outside a castle that had been under siege for a month, took place on a large red carpet in order to provide some semblance of ceremony. As it was associated wth the end of a bloody siege, Aizu people remember it to this day as the kyūketsusen, the blood-sucking carpet.

The carpet, on which Aizu was finally spared further bloodshed, was acquired thanks to Adachi.

Retirement

Unlike many Aizu leaders, Adachi was neither imprisoned nor executed upon the Boshin War’s end. He later returned to his hometown in Tajima and continued his involvement with ginseng cultivation and trade. But while he was still in Nagasaki in the early Meiji era, he was involved in the early education of young Aizu warrior Kusaka Yoshio, who went on to become governor of Nagasaki and then governor of his native Fukushima Prefecture.

And today, there are three primary ginseng growing regions in Japan: Nagasaki, Hyogo– which used to be Tajima Province– and Aizu.

An Apt Scholar

We begin this week in what’s now Kami, Miyagi Prefecture, but back in the days of Sendai domain. Yokoo Tōsaku was born there in 1839, the son of a doctor, and he seems to have shown great promise as a scholar from a young age. Studying first at the Yōkendō Academy in Sendai, then in Edo at the shogunate’s Shoheizaka Academy, Yokoo followed the path of many of his contemporaries in the warrior caste who pursued advanced education. Going to the Shoheizaka Academy was the equivalent of going to graduate school, so it’s not that unusual a thing to have done.

What I think is more unusual and interesting is that he went on to study English, and develop a keen awareness of the world beyond Japan.

A Well-Connected English Language Education

Sendai domain Edo-based liaison officer and Commissioner of Finance Ōwara Shindayu recommended Yokoo for further study, first with Fukuzawa Yukichi at the Keiō Gijuku (today’s Keiō University) and then with missionary Samuel Robbins Brown. Ōwara was one of the forward thinking Sendai domain leaders responsible for the education of people who went on to prominence in both the domain as well as Meiji Japan. Yokoo was one. Another, far more famous, was Takahashi Korekiyo, later Prime Minister and Finance Minister. Takahashi studied with James Curtis Hepburn. You might not be familiar with Hepburn’s name, but if you’ve seen how I render Japanese words in the Latin alphabet in blogposts, you’ve seen a modified version of the romanization system that Hepburn invented. Takahashi, Yokoo, and other Sendai warriors of their time joined the ranks of Japanese people with English language skill, a population that was rapidly growing since the Phaeton Incident forced the Tokugawa Shogunate to rapidly bootstrap its capability in the English language.

Incidentally, one of Yokoo’s classmates in Brown’s tutelage was a Matsuyama retainer named Oshikawa Masayoshi. Oshikawa, together with William F. Hoy, founded Tohoku Gakuin University, one of Sendai’s preeminent institutions of higher learning which I am proud to call an alma mater.

But that’s a story for another time.

Tohoku Makes a Case to the World

Because of Yokoo’s skill in English, Sendai domain orders came down placing him as an English language instructor at Yōkendō Academy. But then the war came, and Sendai domain rallied the Northern Alliance in its fight against the Sat-cho dominated imperial forces. And far from a reactionary conservative last stand of the old order, the Alliance had a foreign policy agenda, which it hoped to pursue by way of presenting its case to the foreign diplomatic corps in Japan, first in the newly opened port of Niigata and then after a secret trip aboard the British merchant vessel Albion, in Yokohama. Yokoo headed the delegation that argued the Alliance’s case before the representatives of 11 countries. He did not succeed; however, he made enough of an impression locally that word got out that he was in greater Edo, and the imperial government put a price on his head, dead or alive. They did not manage to capture him before the war’s end. Yokoo escaped safely aboard one of Enomoto Takeaki’s ships and made it back to Sendai Domain via Sabusawa Island.

After the war, he was again involved in English language education in Sendai, teaching at the Shinbikan, one of the domain’s post-Boshin War schools which went on to be a predecessor of Miyagi Prefectural Sendai Daiichi High School. But a new career soon took Yokoo to greater Tokyo, where he served in a variety of government positions in Kanagawa Prefecture and Tokyo proper, including the Tokyo Metropolitan Police Department. However, Yokoo was also one of many vocal proponents of something called Nanshinron.

Empire and Expansionism

Nanshinron was a doctrine in the empire that advocated for its attention toward and expansion south and east into the islands of the Pacific. Yokoo himself is on record as having argued for Japanese settlement on the Philippine islands of Palawan, Sulu, and Mindanao. And in 1887, Yokoo petitioned Enomoto Takeaki– now Minister of Communications and Transportation– who allowed Yokoo to take a survey trip aboard the Glasgow-built lighthouse ship and later imperial yacht Meiji maru. The voyage surveyed the islands that comprise the Kazan-retto, the Volcano Islands, including one with curious black sand and a mountain on one corner. This trip became the impetus for Japan’s formal annexation of the islands a few years later. They were settled by people from the Izu Islands, which lie some distance to the north, between the Volcano Islands and Honshu itself. A few decades later they played a strategic role in the later stages of the Pacific War, when the allied forces fought to take them over and use them as forward bases in the campaign against the home islands of Japan, in 1945. Some of the most iconic photos of the Pacific War, arguably of the 20th Century as a whole, were taken on those islands that Yokoo surveyed.

Yokoo remained a proponent of Nanshinron for the rest of his life. He died suddenly in 1903, while visiting Tomita Tetsunosuke, a friend and fellow ex-Date retainer– a colleague of Takahashi, who we mentioned earlier– who’d risen to serve variously as governor of Tokyo and governor of the Bank of Japan.
